questions.text: A newborn baby has a characteristic rash as shown below. On examination, bilateral pearly white nuclear cataracts are noted, and a continuous murmur is auscultated. What family does the virus implicated in this syndrome belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of bilateral nuclear cataracts, blueberry muffin rash (image), and patent ductus arteriosus(murmur) suggest congenital rubella syndrome. Rubella virus belongs to the family Matonaviridae.

Rubella virus previously belonged to family Togaviridae, but has been recently changed to family Matonaviridae by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of viruses (ICTV), making it the sole genus under the family Matonaviridae. 

 Option A: Rhabdoviridae includes Rabies virus.

Option B: Filoviridae includes Marburg virus and Ebola virus.

Option D: Calciviridae includes Norwalk agent.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A brain biopsy done at the time of autopsy shows spongiform encephalopathy. Which of the following is unlikely to be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Spongiform encephalopathy is a feature of prion disease. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a prion disease. 

SSPE is a rare and chronic form of progressive brain inflammation caused by a persistent infection with the measles virus. 

Slow virus diseases are characterized by a long asymptomatic period, often months or years in duration, between the introduction of the infectious agent and the appearance of clinical illness. Examples: AIDS, Kuru, CJD, SSPE, PML

CJD, Kuru, and mad cow disease are classified under slow virus diseases which are caused by prions.

questions.text: Which strain of the Ebola virus has the highest case fatality rate?
questions.solution:
The Zaire strain has a case fatality rate of 90%

There are five identified Ebola virus strains, four of which are known to cause disease in humans:

  1. Ebola virus (Zaire ebolavirus)
  2. Sudan virus (Sudan ebolavirus)
  3. Taï Forest virus (Taï Forest ebolavirus)
  4. Bundibugyo virus (Bundibugyo ebolavirus).

The fifth, Reston virus (Reston ebolavirus), has caused disease in nonhuman primates, but not in humans.

The Bundibugyo ebolavirus, Zaire ebolavirus, and Sudan ebolavirus have been associated with large outbreaks in Africa. The strain that caused the 2014–2016 West African outbreak belongs to the Zaire ebolavirus species.

On 14th October 2020, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration(FDA) approved Inmazeb (atoltivimab, maftivimab, and odesivimab-ebgn), a mixture of three monoclonal antibodies, as the first FDA-approved treatment for Zaire ebolavirus (Ebola virus) infection in adult and pediatric patients.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a leading cause of diarrheal death in children?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus is a leading cause of diarrheal death among children in the developing world.

Rotavirus infections occur in most children below the age of 5 years and are most frequent between 6-24 months of age. Neonatal infections are common but are often asymptomatic or mild.

Vaccines for rotavirus: RotaTeq and Rotarix, given orally.

Note: Viruses that can cause diarrhoea in children include: 

  • Rotavirus (most common)
  • Norwalk virus
  • Adenovirus- types 40 and 41 
  • Astrovirus
  • Coronavirus
  • Sapovirus

questions.text: An 18-year-old went on an exchange program to Singapore. An adventurous eater, she tried clams and oysters on a cruise ship. 2 days later, she developed fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of Norwalk infection. It is the most common cause of diarrhea in older children and adults. 

They occur in group settings such as banquet halls, cruise ships, dormitories, and campgrounds, where outbreak sources are usually contaminated food and/or water. Potential sources of contaminated food include shellfish such as clams and oysters, which are contaminated by water. 

Clinical features are nausea, vomiting, watery diarrhea, abdominal pain. Symptoms of gastroenteritis develop 12 to 48 hours after being exposed to norovirus.

The image below is an electron micrograph of Norovirus (Norwalk virus).

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady with recent onset, progressive dementia comes with myoclonus. The brain imaging is shown below. What biochemical component is responsible for this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and imaging suggest a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease(CJD), caused by prions. Prions are composed of protein.

These are infectious protein particles that lack any nucleic acid. They are filterable like viruses but are resistant to agents of sterilization. 

Prion proteins have two isoforms:

  • PrPSc is the prion protein that causes disease.
  • PrPc is the normal prion protein, found in human cells.

Prions cause diseases such as CJD, Kuru, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's.

Laboratory diagnosis of prion diseases:

  • Measurement of PrPSc by immunoassay
  • Brain MRI
  • Brain biopsy
  • Stress protein 14-3-3
  • Sequencing PRNP gene
  • Abnormal EEG

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady is admitted to the ICU with COVID-19.  Which of the following statements is false regarding the organism causing it?

choices.text: These viruses have club-shaped peplomers on their surface
It acts by binding to ACE1 and TMPRSS4 receptors

questions.solution:
The coronavirus spike protein binds to the ACE2 and TMPRSS2 receptors to enter the human cells.

Coronaviruses are a group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped RNA viruses having club or petal-shaped peplomers. Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on their surface.

It spreads through coughing, sneezing, and close personal contact such as touching the mouth, nose. 

The virus is highly mutable and so vaccine prophylaxis for all strains is difficult.

Coronaviruses cause upper respiratory tract infections, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), and Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome (MERS). They spread by inhalation of the virus present in droplets or aerosols of respiratory secretions of the patients. 

 Basic protective measures against the new coronavirus: (SARS-CoV-2)

  • Wash your hands frequently for at least 20 seconds.
  • Maintain social distancing- Maintain at least 1 meter distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth
  • Practice respiratory hygiene- cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when you cough or sneeze, then dispose of the used tissue immediately.
  • If you have fever, cough, and difficulty breathing, seek medical care early
  • Stay informed and follow the advice given by your healthcare provider

The recent emergence of OMICRON, a SARS-CoV-2 variant, has been classified as one of the variants of concern. Notably, fifteen of these mutations reside in spike glycoprotein's receptor-binding domain (RBD), which may alter transmissibility, infectivity, neutralizing antibody escape, and vaccine breakthrough cases of COVID-19.

questions.text: A person who comes in contact with a case of coronavirus (COVID- 19)  needs to be followed up for __________.
questions.solution:
A person who comes in contact with a coronavirus(COVID-19) case (confirmed or probable) needs to be followed up for apperance of symptoms of coronavirus for the maximum incubation period of 14 days.

Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment recommended for COVID-19. People with COVID-19 should receive supportive care to help relieve symptoms. For severe cases, treatment should include care to support vital organ functions.

Basic protective measures against the new coronavirus: (SARS CoV 2)

  • Wash your hands frequently for atleast 20 seconds.
  • Maintain social distancing- Maintain at least 1 metre distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth
  • Practice respiratory hygiene- cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when you cough or sneeze, then dispose of the used tissue immediately.
  • If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical care early
  • Stay informed and follow advice given by your healthcare provider

Old age, Neutrophilia, Increased lactate dehydrogenase and D-dimer levels has been recognised as a significant risk factor for the development of ARDS and death in patients with COVID19.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing testing for SARS-CoV, a FELUDA test is done. Which of the following statements is false about this technology?

choices.text: It is the acronym for FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay
Based on CRISPR gene editing technology
It is slower than RT PCR in detecting SARS-CoV2
It uses CAS-9 protein to bind to the viral signature

questions.solution:
FELUDA is faster than RT-PCR in detecting SARS-CoV2.

FELUDA (FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay) is a newly approved method based on CRISPR gene-editing technology to identify and target the genetic material of SARS-CoV2. 

The CRISPR technology uses a highly specific CAS9 protein to find and bind to the target Covid signature. This is then coupled with paper-strip chemistry to elicit a visual readout on a paper strip.

It is a very affordable, sensitive (96%), and specific (98%) strip test which can detect viral genetic material within 45 minutes. 

It has been developed in India and approved by the Council of Scientific & Industrial Research to aid in the diagnosis of SARS-CoV2.

questions.text: A confirmed case of which of the following viral haemorrhagic fevers was found in India?
questions.solution:
Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever, is caused by Nairovirus species.

It is zoonotic in origin with ticks as vectors. The outbreak was caused due to person-to-person transmission in hospitals.

questions.text: A woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test, 1 month after taking the MMR vaccine. At the time of receiving the vaccine, she had been advised to avoid conception. What advice do you give her now?

choices.text: Low risk; termination of pregnancy may be considered
High risk of anomalies; serious consideration for termination

questions.solution:
In this case scenario, the doctor should advise the patient to wait and watch.

The vaccine should not be administered during pregnancy. If pregnancy occurs within 28 days of immunization, the patient should be counseled on the theoretical risks for the fetus.

Studies of over 200 women who had been inadvertently immunized with rubella vaccine during pregnancy showed that none of their offspring developed congenital rubella syndrome. Therefore, termination of pregnancy is probably not warranted.

questions.text: While working at a WHO outreach post in Africa, you conduct an educational program about the Zika virus. What family does this virus belong to?
questions.solution:
Zika virus belongs to the family Flaviviridae.

It is classified by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV):

  • Family: Flaviviridae
  • Genus: Flavivirus
  • Species: Zika virus

Zika virus is an RNA virus that is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquito bite and by sexual contact. It causes microcephaly and is associated with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome. 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia

  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

questions.text: Which of the following features do not support a diagnosis of Zika fever?
questions.solution:
A petechial rash is not a primary feature of Zika virus infection. 

Though petechiae may rarely appear in Zika virus disease it is however not included in the CDC case definition of Zika virus disease. Petechial rash points towards a diagnosis of dengue fever while a maculopapular rash suggests a Zika virus disease.

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache, and malaise. A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

The complications of Zika virus are:

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Fetal microcephaly in pregnant women.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is-
questions.solution:
The transplacental transmission of Zika virus given in the image causes microcephaly.

The condition shown in the image is microcephaly. It is caused by Zika virus transmission from an infected pregnant mother to her child. Zika virus is a mosquito-borne Flavivirus mainly transmitted through Aedes aegypti.

Symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days. 

  • Fever
  • Rash
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Muscle and joint pain 
  • Malaise
  • Headache
  • In pregnancy- congenital Zika syndrome or microcephaly

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

NCDC Delhi and the National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that have the capacity to provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage. RT-PCR is the standard test available for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection.

questions.text: Tropical spastic paraparesis is caused by:
questions.solution:
is the causative agent of the neurodegenerative disorder  HTLV-1-associated myelopathy or tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP).

The condition resembles multiple sclerosis and is associated with progressive weakness of legs and lower body. The patients develop spastic paraparesis or paraplegia, hyperreflexia, ankle clonus, and extensor plantar response. The disease progresses slowly and takes the form of thoracic myelopathy.

Other conditions caused by HTLV-1 include:

  • Adult T-cell leukemias and lymphomas (ATL)
  • Uveitis
  • Infective dermatitis
  • Arthritis
  • Sjögren’s syndrome

questions.text: What family does the Nipah virus belong to?
questions.solution:
Nipah virus belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae.

Togaviridae contains chikungunya virus.

Flaviviridae contains yellow fever virus, dengue virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, hepatitis C virus, Zika virus

Bunyaviridae contains sandfly fever virus, hantaviruses.
